message.content:
{
  "design_type": "cluster_rct",
  "unit_of_randomization_canonical": "village",
  "is_clustered": true,
  "analysis_unit_canonical": null,
  "primary_outcomes_dedup": [
    "Digital Connectivity",
    "Agency",
    "Gender Attitude Index (GAI)",
    "Digital Literacy Transfer Index (DLTI)",
    "Economic Empowerment"
  ],
  "arms": [
    {
      "arm_id": "arm1_standard_treatment",
      "name": "Standard treatment group",
      "role": "treatment",
      "description": "Village-level assignment to the Standard IVR distance-learning treatment.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq1",
        "eq2"
      ]
    },
    {
      "arm_id": "arm2_extended_treatment",
      "name": "Extended treatment group",
      "role": "treatment",
      "description": "Village-level assignment to the Extended IVR distance-learning treatment.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq1",
        "eq2"
      ]
    },
    {
      "arm_id": "arm3_control",
      "name": "Control group",
      "role": "control",
      "description": "Village-level assignment to the control group (no IVR program).",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq1",
        "eq2"
      ]
    },
    {
      "arm_id": "arm4_merged_treatment",
      "name": "Merged treatment group (Standard + Extended) for this study",
      "role": "treatment",
      "description": "For this study's analysis, the two treatment arms (Standard and Extended) are merged into a single treatment because mothers in both groups received similar intervention.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq3"
      ]
    }
  ],
  "factors": [],
  "assignment_rules": [
    "From a list of 140 villages (from 223 ECD villages), 90 villages were selected for the IVR intervention study sampling frame.",
    "The 90 participating villages were randomized into one of three groups: Standard treatment, Extended treatment, or Control.",
    "Within each village, eligible households were randomly selected from the eligible list, yielding an approximately 1,900-household sample from an approximately 2,400-household baseline frame.",
    "For this study, the Standard and Extended treatment groups are combined into a single treatment group for analysis because the intervention received was similar."
  ],
  "design_completeness": "partial",
  "extraction_sources": [
    "registry"
  ],
  "evidence_quotes": [
    {
      "id": "eq1",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "We will use original sampling design where 90 villages were randomly selected from a list of 140 villages (out of 223 villages from ECD program) and each of the 90 participating villages randomly distributed into one of three groups, i.e., Standard group, Extended group, and Control group (Wang et al., 2024).",
      "supports": "Village-level random assignment; existence of three original arms (Standard, Extended, Control)."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq2",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Due to budget constraints, 90 villages were selected and then randomized into one of two treatments (i.e., Standard and Extended treatments) and a control group.",
      "supports": "Confirms cluster randomization into Standard, Extended, and control."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq3",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "However, for this study, we merged these two treatment groups into one as mothers from both treatment groups received similar intervention.",
      "supports": "This study’s analysis merges Standard and Extended into a single treatment arm."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq4",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Within each village, eligible households were randomly selected.",
      "supports": "Household selection within villages (sampling stage after village-level randomization)."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq5",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "The primary outcomes are -, Digital Connectivity: The Digital Connectivity will quantify the extent of household access to digital technologies among rural Bangladeshi mothers, reflecting their potential for digital engagement in low-resource settings., Agency: By following Kabeer (1999), we conceptualize mothers’ agency through a process through which the mothers make strategic decisions, exert control over their material, human and social resources, and move with freedom, particularly in ways related to their children’s education and their digital connectivity, which is largely restricted by several socio-cultural norms in Bangladeshi society., Gender Attitude Index (GAI): Gender Attitude Index (GAI), an indicator of social norm, will be measured following the method outlined by Dhar et al. (2022). It is designed to capture attitudes towards gender roles, embracing the conception of equality and the more patriarchal concept., Digital Literacy Transfer Index (DLTI): Digital Literacy Transfer Index measures the degree to which mothers introduce newly acquired digital competencies to other family members, particularly children, focusing on their behavioral shifts and role as agents of new technologies within households., Economic Empowerment: Economic Empowerment will be measured in light of the Five Domains of Empowerment (5DE) framework from the Women’s Empowerment in Agriculture Index (WEAI), which assesses empowerment across five key domains: Production, Resources, Income, Leadership, and Time.",
      "supports": "Lists the study’s primary outcomes."
    }
  ],
  "notes": "Design is a village-cluster RCT with three original assignment groups (Standard, Extended, Control), but the registry states that this study merges the two treatment arms into one for analysis. Completeness is marked partial because the registry does not explicitly define the analysis unit (mother vs household) for outcomes and does not explicitly state what the control group receives beyond being labeled control."
}

{
  "design_type": "simple_multiarm",
  "unit_of_randomization_canonical": "individual participant",
  "is_clustered": false,
  "analysis_unit_canonical": null,
  "primary_outcomes_dedup": [
    "Subjective probability of an impossible event (or prize) in the original urn (treated group)",
    "Subjective probability of an impossible event (or prize) in the updated urn (treated group)",
    "Ratio between subjective probabilities of prizes 20 and 100 in the original urn (treated group)",
    "Ratio between subjective probabilities of prizes 20 and 100 in the updated urn (treated group)",
    "Ratio between subjective probabilities of prizes 20 and 100 in the urn (control group)",
    "Willingness to accept to sell the original lottery (treated group)",
    "Willingness to accept to sell the updated lottery (treated group)",
    "Willingness to accept to sell the lottery (control group)"
  ],
  "arms": [
    {
      "arm_id": "A1_control",
      "name": "Control treatment",
      "role": "control",
      "description": "Subjects observe 20 draws from an urn containing 50 prizes of 100 experimental units and 50 prizes of 20 experimental units; they are explicitly told the urn contains two and only two prizes; they report subjective probabilities of the two prizes and willingness to accept (WTA) for selling the lottery determined by a random draw from the urn.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq1"
      ]
    },
    {
      "arm_id": "A2_surprise_good",
      "name": "Surprise treatment – good surprise (E=200)",
      "role": "treatment",
      "description": "Subjects first observe 20 draws from an 'original urn' with 50 prizes of 100 and 50 prizes of 20; report subjective probabilities and WTA for the lottery from the original urn; then 50 prizes of E are added to create an 'updated urn'; subjects observe a new (non-random) draw featuring prize E and then again report subjective probabilities and WTA for the lottery from the modified urn; in this sub-treatment E=200.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq2",
        "eq3"
      ]
    },
    {
      "arm_id": "A3_surprise_bad",
      "name": "Surprise treatment – bad surprise (E=10)",
      "role": "treatment",
      "description": "Same surprise-treatment procedure as above (original urn elicitation, then urn update by adding 50 prizes of E, then a non-random draw featuring E, then re-elicitation from updated urn), with E=10.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq2",
        "eq3"
      ]
    }
  ],
  "factors": [],
  "assignment_rules": [
    "Between-subject assignment to either a control treatment or a surprise treatment, with the surprise treatment further split into two sub-treatments (good surprise E=200 vs bad surprise E=10)."
  ],
  "design_completeness": "partial",
  "extraction_sources": [
    "registry"
  ],
  "evidence_quotes": [
    {
      "id": "eq1",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "In the control treatment: Subjects observe 20 draws from a urn containing 50 prizes of 100 experimental units and 50 prizes of 20 Experimental units and they are explicitly told that they urn contains two and only two prizes. They need to report the subjective probabilities of the two prizes and their willingness to accept for selling the lottery determined by a random draw from the urn.",
      "supports": "Control arm description and presence of an explicitly labeled control treatment."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq2",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "In the surprise treatment: Subjects observe 20 draws from a urn -- that we call \"original urn\" containing 50 prizes of 100 experimental units and 50 prizes of 20 Experimental units. They are asked to report the subjective probabilities of the two prizes and their willingness to accept for selling the lottery determined by a random draw from the original urn. Then we add to the original urn -- that we call now \"updated\" urn -- 50 prizes of E experimental units and we ask subjects to observe a new draw from the updated urn. This is a non random draw featuring the prize E. Subjects after observing E, and without other information are asked again to report the subjective probabilities of the two prizes and their willingness to accept for selling the lottery determined by a random draw from the modified urn.",
      "supports": "Surprise-treatment procedure (original urn elicitation, urn update with E, non-random draw featuring E, re-elicitation)."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq3",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "In the surprise treatment we further distinguish two different sub-treatments one where the prizes added is E = 200 units - the good surprise treatment; and the other where the prizes added is E = 10 units - the bad surprise treatment.",
      "supports": "Two surprise sub-treatments/arms: good surprise (E=200) and bad surprise (E=10)."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq4",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "(i) The subjective probability of an impossible event (or prize) in the original urn for treated group, (ii) The subjective probability of an impossible event (or prize) in the updated urn for treated group, (iii) The ratio between subjective probabilities of the prizes 20 and 100 respectively in the original urn for the treated group, (iv) The ratio between subjective probabilities of the prizes 20 and 100 respectively in the updated urn for the treated group, (v) The ratio between subjective probabilities of the prizes 20 and 100 respectively in the urn for the control group, (vi) The willingness to accept to sell the original lottery in the treated group, (vii) The willingness to accept to sell the updated lottery in the treated group, (viii) The willingness to accept to sell the lottery in the control group",
      "supports": "Primary outcomes list."
    }
  ],
  "notes": "Design is treated as simple multiarm with three arms (control, surprise-good, surprise-bad). The registry text does not explicitly state the randomization mechanism or probabilities, only that there are treatments/sub-treatments; therefore design completeness is marked partial. Unit of randomization is inferred as individual participants because the intervention is administered to 'subjects' online with no mention of cluster-level assignment."
}

{
  "design_type": "cluster_rct",
  "unit_of_randomization_canonical": "healthcare facility",
  "is_clustered": true,
  "analysis_unit_canonical": null,
  "primary_outcomes_dedup": [
    "Range of contraceptive methods offered",
    "Overall quality of counseling services",
    "Provider interpersonal skills",
    "Provider overall knowledge",
    "Record-keeping",
    "Loan applications",
    "Current loans",
    "Revenue generation"
  ],
  "arms": [
    {
      "arm_id": "arm1",
      "name": "Trainings treatment (offer of comprehensive training package plus supportive supervision/complementary services)",
      "role": "treatment",
      "description": "Private health providers/facilities were offered a comprehensive package of training sessions (counseling skills, contraceptive technology update, clinical skills, business practices). Providers could choose which sessions (if any) their staff attended; supportive supervision and complementary services were also offered. Analysis described as intent-to-treat based on offer.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq1",
        "eq2"
      ]
    },
    {
      "arm_id": "arm2",
      "name": "Control (no training package or complementary services offered)",
      "role": "control",
      "description": "Private health providers/facilities were not offered any elements of the training package or complementary services.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq3",
        "eq2"
      ]
    }
  ],
  "factors": [],
  "assignment_rules": [
    "Baseline survey conducted prior to randomization; endline survey conducted after assignment.",
    "965 private healthcare facilities were randomly assigned to treatment (484 facilities) or control (481 facilities).",
    "Randomization was stratified: first by 20 local government areas (LGAs) forming primary strata/cells (ensuring at least four facilities per cell).",
    "For primary cells with more than 16 facilities, sub-strata were created by splitting above/below median vignette score, and within those sub-strata splitting above/below median business score, creating final cells.",
    "Within each final cell, facilities were randomly assigned one-by-one to treatment or control."
  ],
  "design_completeness": "complete",
  "extraction_sources": [
    "registry"
  ],
  "evidence_quotes": [
    {
      "id": "eq1",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Trainings Treatment: Private health providers were offered a comprehensive training package that included sessions on counseling skills, contraceptive technology update, clinical skills, and business practices. The providers then decided which training sessions, if any, their staff would participate in. Supportive supervision services, and other complementary services were also offered.",
      "supports": "Treatment arm content and the fact that uptake/participation was provider-chosen; inclusion of supportive supervision/complementary services."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq2",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "We randomly assigned those 965 private health facilities into either a treatment group (484 facilities) or a control group (481 facilities)...",
      "supports": "Unit of randomization (facilities) and the two-arm assignment with sample sizes."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq3",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Control: Private health providers were not offered any elements of the training package or complimentary services.",
      "supports": "Control arm definition."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq4",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Since each private health provider independently chose which training sessions and complimentary services to take advantage of, our analysis employs an “intent-to-treat” approach to examine the impact of offering the multi-faceted intervention, regardless of participation in the training sessions.",
      "supports": "Intent-to-treat framing based on offer rather than participation."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq5",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "First, we created strata for each of the 20 local government areas, or LGA, creating 20 “primary cells.” We made sure that each cell contained at least four facilities in order to avoid sparsely populated cells.",
      "supports": "First stratification step: LGA-based primary strata/cells and minimum cell size rule."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq6",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "For primary cells with more than 16 facilities, we created sub-strata by splitting the primary strata into those above and below the median vignette score (defined below) and, within each of the resulting sub-strata, splitting again into those above and below the median business score . Thus, we created “final cells,” which were groupings of facilities from the same LGA and, if the sample size permitted, were also similar in terms of the vignette score and business score.",
      "supports": "Sub-stratification procedure and definition of final cells."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq7",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Finally, we randomly assigned all 965 facilities, one by one within each of those ‘final cells’ to either a control or treatment group.",
      "supports": "Final assignment rule: within-final-cell randomization to treatment vs control."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq8",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Healthcare: the range of contraceptive methods offered, overall quality of counseling services, provider interpersonal skills, provider overall knowledge., Business Practices: record-keeping, loan applications, current loans, revenue generation.",
      "supports": "Primary outcomes."
    }
  ],
  "notes": "Classified as cluster_rct because randomization is at the healthcare facility level (not individual patients/providers). No explicit statement of the analysis unit beyond facility-level assignment and facility surveys, so analysis_unit_canonical left null per instructions."
}

{
  "design_type": "simple_multiarm",
  "unit_of_randomization_canonical": "sub-district",
  "is_clustered": true,
  "analysis_unit_canonical": null,
  "primary_outcomes_dedup": [
    "livestock assets",
    "income",
    "herd-related investments",
    "home consumption of livestock",
    "consumption expenditures"
  ],
  "arms": [
    {
      "arm_id": "a1_control",
      "name": "Control (no cash transfer)",
      "role": "control",
      "description": "Eligible households in sub-districts not selected for treatment were allocated to the control group (no unconditional cash transfer from the study intervention).",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq3"
      ]
    },
    {
      "arm_id": "a2_cash_177",
      "name": "Unconditional cash transfer (USD 177)",
      "role": "treatment",
      "description": "Eligible households in 25 treated sub-districts received a one-off unconditional cash transfer of USD 177 (via bank transfer) implemented by People in Need (PIN).",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq4",
        "eq5"
      ]
    },
    {
      "arm_id": "a3_cash_295",
      "name": "Unconditional cash transfer (USD 295)",
      "role": "treatment",
      "description": "Eligible households in 25 treated sub-districts received a one-off unconditional cash transfer of USD 295 (via bank transfer) implemented by People in Need (PIN).",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq4",
        "eq5"
      ]
    }
  ],
  "factors": [],
  "assignment_rules": [
    "Study sample: households eligible if (i) in the panel survey sample, (ii) located in areas projected at very high/high/medium risk of extreme winter conditions per IRIMHE risk map (Jan 10, 2021), and (iii) own livestock.",
    "Among 925 eligible households, assignment to treatment vs control was by random lottery implemented in STATA.",
    "Randomization was conducted at the sub-district level: 50 of 111 sub-districts were randomly selected for treatment; remaining sub-districts formed control.",
    "Within treated sub-districts, 25 sub-districts were assigned to cash amount USD 177 and 25 sub-districts to cash amount USD 295."
  ],
  "design_completeness": "complete",
  "extraction_sources": [
    "registry"
  ],
  "evidence_quotes": [
    {
      "id": "eq1",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "The relevant population for the cash transfer intervention is households that fulfill three eligibility criteria: i) they must be sample households of the Coping with Shocks in Mongolia Household Panel Survey, ii) they must live in an area projected to be at very high, high, or medium risk of experiencing extreme winter conditions, according to a risk map published by IRIMHE on January 10, 2021, and (iii) they must own livestock.",
      "supports": "Eligibility criteria / sampling frame definition"
    },
    {
      "id": "eq2",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Based on the latest available data, a study sample of 925 households meeting the three eligibility criteria was selected.",
      "supports": "Eligible sample size (N=925 households)"
    },
    {
      "id": "eq3",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Among these 925 eligible households, 421 were assigned to the treatment group, while 504 were allocated to the control group through a random lottery implemented in STATA by the authors.",
      "supports": "Existence of treatment vs control groups; assignment method; counts"
    },
    {
      "id": "eq4",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Randomization was conducted on the sub-district level (using the latest information on the sub-district of residence available in February 2021). The 925 eligible households lived in 111 sub-districts. 50 sub-districts were randomly selected to comprise the treatment group.",
      "supports": "Unit of randomization is sub-district; cluster assignment; treated clusters count"
    },
    {
      "id": "eq5",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "The 50 sub-districts in the treatment group were assigned to two treatment arms with varying values for the cash transfer. Eligible households in 25 sub-districts in the treatment group were assigned to receive a cash transfer of 177 USD, while eligible households in the other 25 sub-districts in the treatment group were assigned to receive a cash transfer of 295 USD.",
      "supports": "Multi-arm structure within treatment: two cash amounts; cluster-level assignment to cash amount"
    },
    {
      "id": "eq6",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "livestock assets, income, herd-related investments, home consumption of livestock, and consumption expenditures",
      "supports": "Primary outcomes list"
    }
  ],
  "notes": "Design is a clustered, multi-arm RCT: sub-districts were randomized to control vs treatment, and treated sub-districts were further split into two cash-transfer amounts (USD 177 vs USD 295). The registry text does not explicitly state the analysis unit (household vs individual), though the sample is described as households."
}

{
  "design_type": "simple_multiarm",
  "unit_of_randomization_canonical": "firm-pair (seller-buyer match)",
  "is_clustered": true,
  "analysis_unit_canonical": null,
  "primary_outcomes_dedup": [
    "Amendment of past returns (binary)",
    "Amount amended (in million UGX)",
    "Change in pre-treatment VAT liability after amendment (in million UGX)",
    "Actual vs. predicted VAT liability in post-treatment returns",
    "Probability that the VAT liability is positive",
    "Probability that VAT liability in a given month is higher than the VAT liability in the same month the year before",
    "Probability of misreporting",
    "Amount misreported",
    "Probability of underreporting",
    "Amount underreported",
    "Continuation of the trading relationship",
    "Reported transaction volume for the pair (in million UGX)"
  ],
  "arms": [
    {
      "arm_id": "arm1_control",
      "name": "Control group",
      "role": "control",
      "description": "No notification letter (control group).",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq3",
        "eq4"
      ]
    },
    {
      "arm_id": "arm2_buyer_only",
      "name": "Letter to buyer only",
      "role": "treatment",
      "description": "Notification letter sent only to the buyer in the selected seller-buyer pair.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq3"
      ]
    },
    {
      "arm_id": "arm3_seller_only",
      "name": "Letter to seller only",
      "role": "treatment",
      "description": "Notification letter sent only to the seller in the selected seller-buyer pair.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq3"
      ]
    },
    {
      "arm_id": "arm4_both_buyer_seller",
      "name": "Letters to both buyer and seller",
      "role": "treatment",
      "description": "Notification letters sent to both buyer and seller in the selected pair.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq3"
      ]
    }
  ],
  "factors": [],
  "assignment_rules": [
    "Construct a base sample of firm-pairs meeting eligibility criteria (VAT-registered; filed a VAT return in the last month; not in URA annual audit plan for FY 2017/18; accumulated discrepancy above 1 million UGX over previous 10 months).",
    "Iteratively select firm-pairs into the study sample by random selection, removing all trading partners of the two firms in each selected pair from the base sample; resulting study sample has pairs separated by at least two nodes in the transaction network and with accumulated misreporting discrepancy > ~270 USD over the past year.",
    "Apply stratified randomization to allocate firm-pairs in the study sample to three treatment arms and a control group.",
    "Random assignment shares: 40% control; remaining 60% split equally across three treatment arms.",
    "Stratification variables: ratio of sales to final consumers; firm size (total revenue from sales); headquarters in vs. outside Kampala."
  ],
  "design_completeness": "complete",
  "extraction_sources": [
    "registry"
  ],
  "evidence_quotes": [
    {
      "id": "eq1",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "The intervention consists of sending notification letters to a randomly-selected sample of firm pairs (i.e., a seller-buyer match) for which reporting discrepancies were observed in the year before the intervention.",
      "supports": "Intervention modality; assignment unit described as firm pairs."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq2",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Once the first firm-pair is randomly selected, we remove all the trading partners of the two firms (buyer and seller) from the base sample. Then, we randomly select another firm-pair and remove all their trading partners.",
      "supports": "Study-sample selection rule (iterative procedure) affecting eligible units prior to treatment assignment."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq3",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "In the third step, we apply a stratified randomization procedure to allocate firms from the study sample to three treatment arms and a control group. In the first treatment arm, the letter is sent only to the buyer in the selected pair. In the second treatment arm, the letter is sent to the seller. Finally, in the third arm, letters are sent to both the buyer and seller.",
      "supports": "Existence of control group and three treatment arms; definitions of the three treatment arms."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq4",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "In the third step, we randomly assign 40% of firms (677) to be part of the control group. The remaining 60% (996) are divided up equally across the three treatment arms. In this randomization process, we stratify by the ratio of sales to final consumers, firm size (measured by total revenue from sales), and by whether or not the firms' headquarters are located in or outside Kampala (the capital city of Uganda).",
      "supports": "Assignment proportions and stratification variables."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq5",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Retrospective outcomes: amendment of past returns (binary), amount amended (in million UGX), change in pre-treatment VAT liability after amendment (in million UGX)., Forward-looking outcomes: actual vs. predicted VAT liability in post-treatment returns, probability that the VAT liability is positive, probability that VAT liability in a given month is higher than the VAT liability in the same month the year before, probability of misreporting, amount misreported, probability of underreporting, amount underreported, continuation of the trading relationship, reported transaction volume for the pair (in million UGX).",
      "supports": "Primary outcomes list."
    }
  ],
  "notes": "Randomization is described over 'firm-pairs' (seller-buyer matches) and treatment varies by whether the buyer, seller, or both receive a monitoring letter. The registry text sometimes says 'allocate firms' and reports counts as 'firms (677)' even though the sampling frame is firm-pairs; this extraction treats the experimental units as firm-pairs because treatment is defined at the pair level ('in the selected pair') and the intervention is stated as being sent to a sample of firm pairs."
}

{
  "design_type": "cluster_rct",
  "unit_of_randomization_canonical": "school",
  "is_clustered": true,
  "analysis_unit_canonical": null,
  "primary_outcomes_dedup": [
    "Time spent on instructional tasks",
    "Student achievement in math",
    "Students' socio-emotional skills"
  ],
  "arms": [],
  "factors": [],
  "assignment_rules": [
    "55 public secondary schools in the Santiago metropolitan area were invited; 52 accepted to participate.",
    "Within participating schools, two grade 1 and two grade 3 sections per school were randomly selected.",
    "Baseline data collection produced a roster of 3,300 students entered into a lottery roster (suggesting random assignment via lottery), but the registry text does not state what entities were randomized to which intervention(s) or how many arms existed."
  ],
  "design_completeness": "unclear",
  "extraction_sources": [
    "registry"
  ],
  "evidence_quotes": [
    {
      "id": "eq1",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "We invited 55 public secondary schools in the Santiago metropolitan area to participate in the study.",
      "supports": "Study sampling frame includes schools (implying a school-based/cluster setting)."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq2",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "52 schools accepted to participate.",
      "supports": "Number of participating schools."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq3",

      "quote": "We randomly selected two grade 1 and two grade 3 sections per school.",

      "source_doc": "registry",

      "supports": "Primary outcomes."
    }
  ],
  "notes": "The registry excerpt describes recruitment of schools and random sampling of sections within schools, plus creation of a student lottery roster, but it does not specify the intervention(s), treatment/control arms, or the unit actually randomized to treatment. Because the setting is school-based and selection is explicitly within schools, the design is treated as clustered (school-based) for unit-of-randomization purposes, but arm structure cannot be recovered from the provided text."
}

{
  "design_type": "simple_multiarm",
  "unit_of_randomization_canonical": "trial registry entry (study-level)",
  "is_clustered": true,
  "analysis_unit_canonical": null,
  "primary_outcomes_dedup": [
    "Email open rate",
    "Page visit rate",
    "Index of research results reported"
  ],
  "arms": [
    {
      "arm_id": "arm1_control",
      "name": "Control",
      "role": "control",
      "description": "Control condition (email content corresponds to control assignment for a given trial entry/registration).",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq1",
        "eq2"
      ]
    },
    {
      "arm_id": "arm2_t1_salience_missing_info",
      "name": "Treatment 1: Salience of missing information nudge",
      "role": "treatment",
      "description": "Email nudge emphasizing salience of missing/missing-information fields to prompt collaborators to update post-trial fields on their registration.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq1",
        "eq3",
        "eq4"
      ]
    },
    {
      "arm_id": "arm3_t2_lottery",
      "name": "Treatment 2: Lottery nudge",
      "role": "treatment",
      "description": "Email nudge including a lottery incentive intended to prompt collaborators to update post-trial fields on their registration.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq1",
        "eq3",
        "eq4"
      ]
    }
  ],
  "factors": [],
  "assignment_rules": [
    "All studies/trial entries are randomized into one of three arms (two treatments and a control).",
    "Randomization is at the trial entry level (registry-entry level); interventions are delivered to individuals (collaborators) via emails whose content varies by the assigned arm of the registration.",
    "Randomization is stratified into three strata based on collaborator overlap across trials (single-trial PIs, multi-trial PIs, many-trial PIs).",
    "Within each stratum, randomization probabilities are set to weight all three arms evenly to yield near-equal numbers of trial entries per arm within strata.",
    "Individuals listed as collaborators on multiple trials may receive multiple emails and potentially multiple treatment conditions (because assignment is by trial entry)."
  ],
  "design_completeness": "partial",
  "extraction_sources": [
    "registry"
  ],
  "evidence_quotes": [
    {
      "id": "eq1",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "All studies are randomized into one of three arms: two treatments and a control.",
      "supports": "Number of arms and presence of a control arm."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq2",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "The experiment is clustered at the study-level, but interventions will be at the individual-study pair level.",
      "supports": "Unit of randomization is at study-level and delivery occurs at individual-study pair level (clustered design)."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq3",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "This study will test the effectiveness of two types of nudges, \"salience of missing information\" and a lottery, at prompting collaborators to update the post-trial fields on their registration.",
      "supports": "Identifies the two treatment types (Treatment 1 and Treatment 2)."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq4",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "The treatments are randomized at the trial entry level, and each individual in the sample will receive one set of emails (initial and, if needed, follow-up) per registration for which they are listed as a \"collaborator\", with the email content varying depending on whether the registration has been assigned to control, treatment 1, or treatment 2.",
      "supports": "Randomization level (trial entry) and mapping from assigned arm to email content received by collaborators."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq5",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Randomization is stratified by a categorical variable with three values: 1) “single trial PIs”: trials where no collaborator is listed on any other trial; 2) “multi-trial PIs”: trials where at least one collaborator is on at least one other trial, but no collaborators are on five or more other trials; and 3) “many-trial PIs”: trials where at least one collaborator is on at least five other trials.",
      "supports": "Stratification variable and its three strata definitions."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq6",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Within the strata the randomization probability is set to weight all three arms evenly so as to produce three arms per stratum with near-equal numbers of trial entries.",
      "supports": "Equal allocation across arms within each stratum."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq7",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "First-stage outcomes:, Email open rate, Page visit rate, Primary outcome:, Index of research results reported (described in more detail in attached PAP)",
      "supports": "Primary outcomes listed in the registry entry."
    }
  ],
  "notes": "Design is a 3-arm individually-delivered nudge intervention with randomization at the trial registry entry (study) level and emails sent to collaborators per registration. Marked 'partial' because the registry text does not describe the exact content of the control emails nor the detailed operationalization of each nudge beyond the labels, and the analysis unit is not explicitly stated."
}

{
  "design_type": "multistage",

  "is_clustered": false,
  "analysis_unit_canonical": null,
  "primary_outcomes_dedup": [
    "Disbeliefs – Difference between estimated accuracy rates of in-group versus out-group supporters when judging factual statements.",
    "In-group bias in information processing – The extent to which respondents update their judgments more when signals come from in-party members versus out-party members.",
    "Affective polarization – Difference in favorable versus unfavorable feelings toward in-party and out-party supporters, measured using feeling thermometers and comfort measures for social relations."
  ],
  "arms": [
    {
      "arm_id": "arm1_treatment_info_equal_partisan_knowledge",
      "name": "Treatment: information correction (partisan groups perform equally well)",

    },
    {

      "description": "Receives no informational correction prior to post-treatment judgment tasks.",
      "evidence_quote_ids": [
        "eq1",
        "eq2",
        "eq3"
      ]
    }
  ],
  "factors": [],
  "assignment_rules": [
    "Participants are randomly assigned to either a treatment group (receives corrective information about partisan factual knowledge) or a control group (receives no information).",
    "Post-treatment, within each judgment task, respondents are randomly assigned to receive either an in-party or out-party signal about majority opinions (for five tasks).",
    "Additionally, respondents complete two tasks that use education-based signals (college vs. non-college)."
  ],
  "design_completeness": "partial",
  "extraction_sources": [
    "registry"
  ],
  "evidence_quotes": [
    {
      "id": "eq1",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Participants are randomly assigned to either a treatment or control group. The treatment group receives information that supporters of different political parties perform equally well on factual knowledge questions, while the control group receives no information.",
      "supports": "Existence and description of the main between-subject treatment vs control arms."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq2",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Respondents are then randomly split: the treatment group is informed that partisan groups differ by less than 5% in accuracy on the factual questions, while the control group receives no information.",
      "supports": "Main randomization and specific content/threshold (<5%) of treatment information."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq3",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Post-treatment, all respondents complete five additional judgment tasks (three factual, two conspiracy), where each task randomly assigns them either an in-party or out-party signal regarding majority opinions. They also complete two additional tasks with education signals (college vs. non-college).",
      "supports": "Within-respondent (task-level) randomization to signals; presence of education-signal tasks."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq4",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Participants in South Korea and the United States take part in an online survey experiment.",
      "supports": "Setting is an online survey experiment (supports individual-participant unit context)."
    },
    {
      "id": "eq5",
      "source_doc": "registry",
      "quote": "Disbeliefs – Difference between estimated accuracy rates of in-group versus out-group supporters when judging factual statements., In-group bias in information processing – The Extent to which respondents update their judgments more when signals come from in-party members versus out-party members., Affective polarization – Difference in favorable versus unfavorable feelings toward in-party and out-party supporters, measured using feeling thermometers and comfort measures for social relations.",
      "supports": "Primary outcomes."
    }
  ],
  "notes": "Design includes a main between-subject randomization (treatment vs control) plus repeated post-treatment judgment tasks with task-level random assignment to in-party vs out-party signals; because these are multiple stages/levels of randomization rather than a fully enumerated factorial with named cells, coded as multistage. Completeness is partial because the registry text does not clearly enumerate all task-level signal conditions as distinct arms/cells (e.g., whether a no-signal condition exists, and exact mapping of the education-signal tasks)."
}
